_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The ten things that are helpful, should: Mindfulness of the body that is full of pleasure
Contact, which is accompanied by defilements and is prone to being grasped
The heart’s immersion of immediate result
All sentient beings are sustained by food
The unshakable release of the heart
The twenty things that are helpful, shou: Ignorance and craving for continued existence
Being hard to admonish and having bad friends
Being easy to admonish and having good friends
What are the causes and conditions for the corruption of sentient beings, and what are the causes and conditions for the purification of sentient beings
Two knowledges: knowledge of ending, and knowledge of non-arising
Two elements: the conditioned element and the unconditioned element
The thirty things that are helpful, shou: Associating with good people, listening to the true teaching, and practicing in line with the teaching

Three kinds of immersion: immersion with placing the mind and keeping it connected, immersion without placing the mind but just keeping it connected, and immersion without placing the mind or keeping it connected
Three feelings: pleasant, painful, and neutral
Three cravings: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for continued existence, and craving to end existence
Three unskillful roots: greed, hate, and delusion
Three skillful roots: non-greed, non-hate, and non-delusion
Three elements of escape: renunciation, the formless, and cessation
Three knowledges: regarding the past, future, and present
Three elements: sensuality, form, and formlessness
Three knowledges: recollection of past lives, knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings, and knowledge of the ending of defilements
The forty things that are helpful, shoul: Four situations: living in a suitable region, relying on good people, being rightly resolved in oneself, and past merit
The four kinds of mindfulness meditation: observing an aspect of the body, feelings, mind, and principles
Four foods: solid food, whether coarse or fine; contact, mental intention, and consciousness
Four floods: sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance
Four bonds: sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance
Four kinds of detachment: detachment from the bonds of sensuality, desire for rebirth, views, and ignorance
Four kinds of immersion: immersion liable to decline, stable immersion, immersion that leads to distinction, and immersion that leads to penetration
Four knowledges: knowledge of the present phenomena, inferential knowledge, knowledge of others’ minds, and conventional knowledge
The four noble truths: suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering
Four fruits of the ascetic life: stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.
Five things that are helpful [dn34:1.6.0: Faith in the Realized One’s awakening
Energy for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities
Five things that make things worse [dn34: Anger and upset with spiritual companions
Five things that should be produced (a c: Right immersion that is noble and spiritual
Right immersion not cultivated by sinners
Right immersion that is peaceful and sublime
Mindful entry and emergence from right immersion
Five things that should be directly know: Inspiration from a meditation subject as a foundation of immersion
Six warm-hearted qualities [dn34:1.7.0]: Consistently treating spiritual companions with bodily kindness
Consistently treating spiritual companions with verbal kindness
Consistently treating spiritual companions with mental kindness
Sharing possessions gained by legitimate means
Living according to precepts shared with spiritual companions
Living according to the view shared with spiritual companions
Six kinds of disrespect [dn34:1.7.0]: Lack of respect and reverence for the Teacher
Lack of respect and reverence for the teaching
Lack of respect and reverence for the Saṅgha
Lack of respect and reverence for the training
Lack of respect and reverence for diligence
Lack of respect and reverence for hospitality
Six kinds of respect [dn34:1.7.0]: Respect and reverence for the Teacher
Respect and reverence for the teaching
Respect and reverence for the Saṅgha
Respect and reverence for the training
Six consistent responses (a causal chain: Equanimity when seeing a sight with their eyes
Equanimity when hearing a sound with their ears
Equanimity when smelling an odor with their nose
Equanimity when tasting a flavor with their tongue
Equanimity when feeling a touch with their body
Equanimity when knowing a thought with their mind
Six direct knowledges [dn34:1.7.0]: Understanding the minds of other beings and individuals
Realization of the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life
Seven kinds of wealth of noble ones: the wealth of faith, ethical conduct, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
Seven things that should be developed [d: Seven awakening factors: mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.
Seven things that should be given up (a: Seven underlying tendencies: sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
Seven things that make things worse [dn3: Seven bad qualities: a mendicant is faithless, shameless, imprudent, uneducated, lazy, unmindful, and witless.
Seven things that lead to distinction [d: Seven good qualities: a mendicant is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.
Seven things that are hard to comprehend: Seven aspects of the teachings of the good persons: a mendicant knows the teachings, knows the meaning, knows themselves, knows moderation, knows the right time, knows assemblies, and knows people.
Seven things that should be produced [dn: Seven perceptions: the perception of impermanence, the perception of not-self, the perception of ugliness, the perception of drawbacks, the perception of giving up, the perception of fading away, and the perception of cessation.
Seven things that should be directly kno: Seven qualifications for graduation: a mendicant has a keen enthusiasm to undertake the training, to examine the teachings, to get rid of desires, for retreat, to rouse up energy, for mindfulness and alertness, to penetrate theoretically. And they don’t lose these desires in the future.
Seven things that should be realized [dn: Seven powers of one who has ended the defilements: clear seeing of impermanence, clear seeing of sensual pleasures, mind inclined to seclusion, well-developed four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well-developed five faculties, well-developed seven awakening factors, and well-developed noble eightfold path.
The sixth dimension of mastery [dn34:2.1: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.
They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.
Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color, yellow hue, and yellow tint.
Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
The seventh dimension of mastery (a expa: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color, red hue, and red tint.
Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
The eighth dimension of mastery (a expan: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees visions externally that are white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
Or a cloth from Bāraṇasī that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color, white hue, and white tint.
Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’
The eight liberations (a expanded upon u: Having physical form, they see visions. This is the first liberation.
Not perceiving physical form internally, someone see visions externally. This is the second liberation.
They’re focused only on beauty. This is the third liberation.

Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space. This is the fourth liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness. This is the fifth liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. This is the sixth liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. This is the seventh liberation.
Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling. This is the eighth liberation.
Nine things that should be developed [dn: Trying to be pure in ethics
Trying to be pure in mind
Trying to be pure in view
Knowledge and vision of the variety of paths
Knowledge and vision of the practice
Nine abodes of sentient beings [dn34:2.2: Sentient beings that are diverse in body and diverse in perception
Sentient beings that are diverse in body and unified in perception
Sentient beings that are unified in body and diverse in perception
Sentient beings that are unified in body and unified in perception
Sentient beings that are non-percipient and do not experience anything
Sentient beings that have gone totally beyond perceptions of form
Sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite space
Sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness
Sentient beings that have gone totally beyond the dimension of nothingness
Nine grounds for resentment (a causal ch: They are doing wrong to me
They will do wrong to me
They did wrong by someone I love
They are doing wrong by someone I love
They will do wrong by someone I love
They are helping someone I dislike
They will help someone I dislike
Nine methods to get rid of resentment [d: Thinking: ‘They did wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They will do wrong to me, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They did wrong by someone I love, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They are doing wrong by someone I love, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They will do wrong by someone I love, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They helped someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They are helping someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?’
Thinking: ‘They will help someone I dislike, but what can I possibly do?’
Nine perceptions (a causal chain) [dn34:: The perceptions of repulsiveness in food
The perceptions of dissatisfaction with the whole world
The perceptions of suffering in impermanence
The perceptions of not-self in suffering
Nine progressive meditations [dn34:2.2.0: Dimension of neither perception nor non-perception
Nine progressive cessations [dn34:2.2.0]: Placing of the mind and keeping it connected
Perception of the dimension of infinite space
Perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness
Perception of the dimension of nothingness
